Mike:

Here is the law:

US Constitution, Article 1, Section 7, Clause 1:

All bills for raising Revenue shall originate in the House of Representatives; but the Senate may propose or concur with Amendments as on other Bills.

The House MUST initiate a revenue bill, such as the budget. The Senate does not have legal authority to originate such a bill.

However, the Senate has the right to AMEND such bills.

Both Houses of Congress have to agree on the terms of a final budget bill (or any bill).

You commented:

"Surely, if the GOP control the Congress then they can put a clean bill before the house and vote for its failure."

And if they did so, their PERFIDY would be apparent for all to see.

They would be hanging out there with their pants down around their knees.

And they would get POUNDED in the 2014 election.

(If they fail to put up such a clean bill, they will ALSO get pounded in the 2014 elections. "Be careful what you ask for, because you might get it." Just watch the news on November 5, 2014.)

You're pretty close, and Joe's response was partially correct, but a bit more...

The House has to initiate spending bills,and whether John Boehner admits it or not, there are probably enough Republican votes to pass a 'clean' (no restrictions) bill to fund the US government at current levels, and certainly enough votes to pass a 'clean' increase in the debt limit.

However, the rules of the House (not in the Constitution, but long held) require all House bills to be submitted by the Speaker. So Boehner can and has refused to allow the above bills to be put before the House.

Consider that most economists I've read (including conservative ones) suggest very strongly that refusing to raise the debt limit will very likely have severe consequences not only for the American economy, but also the world's, If so, is this too much power to have in one man's hand? I'll leave this as an 'exercise' for the readers.

Mike -

The Senate and House of Representatives, together, are our Congress. Those persons generally referred to as Congressmen, are technically titled as Representatives, while Senators and Representatives are all technically congressmen, even the women.

Speaker of the House of Representatives John Boehner was appointed head of the House by the Republicans alone, and the Democrats had no say in the matter.

If John Boehner would put the Senate's version of the House budget bill to a vote, it would pass, as there are enough Republican Representatives to join Democrats in approving the budget. It is even possible that most Republicans would vote with the Democrats to pass the budget.

If Speaker John Boehner think the Senate's version of the House budget bill won't pass, why doesn't he put it up to vote to prove its unpopularity? If the House voted on the bill and it failed to pass, wouldn't that take all the pressure off of the Republicans and put all the pressure on the Democrats, and on the Senate, and on President Obama?

But Speaker Boehner refuses to allow the Senate's budget bill to be voted on in the House of Representatives, precisely because Boehner knows it will pass.

I am Australian, so please clarify if I am wrong. My understanding is that the Executive (Obama) has a budget it requires to operate based on legal operations, of which Obamacare is one, however, the Congress is the House that has the authority to pass that budget prior to Senate and POTUS approval.

Congress is now Republican dominated, while the Senate and Whitehouse remain Democrat controlled. As such, the hatred towards Obamacare from the Tea Party can't be overturned via legislation. Therefore, a threat to funding is the best they can do.

This would result in their position being strengthened in saying, we need to negotiate. If they believe that they do not have the numbers to obstruct a clean bill then isn't Boehner undermining the democratic processes prescribed in the US Constitution? If he doesn't have the numbers to achieve his goal, what right has he to not put a clean bill before the House?

Without dogma over what US federalism means, it is obvious it means different things to different sides of politics, and how the US can't keep living in debt or resort to 'socialism', how does the GOP justify their position? I understand their concerns for living within budgetary means but shouldn't they have to win a few more Senate seats and maybe the Presidency to pursue such an agenda? Also, Ted Cruz is Senate why is her interfering in Congress matters?

Therefore, President Obama could have CLOSED EVERY U.S. Government Executive Branch agency (except the active duty military, so that the conservatives could not accuse him of leaving the US open to attack by foreigners, for example the Duchy of Grand Fenwick, led by Peter Sellers - see the movie "The Mouse That Roared').

Had he done so, EVERYONE, including Tea Party low (or NO) information types would have seen exactly what the US Government actually does.

There would be no planes flying because the air traffic controllers and the TSA would be off duty.

There would be NO US Government payments of any type going out to any recipient.

People who were affected would complain to their Representative and Senators, and tell them to get the government back in business.

But President Obama wants to be the "adult" and paper over these issues as best as he can as if things were normal when they are most obviously NOT NORMAL.

Most Americans are too concerned with their private lives to notice what is going on.

This procedure would have been one that the Tea Party would have NO ability to frustrate, because the President alone controls the Executive Branch.

A Political Crisis:

Charles and David Koch, the billionaire brothers with the second biggest fortune in America, are threating to bankroll primary campaigns by Tea Party extremists challenging Republicans in Congress who don’t go along wi...th their crusade to undo the Affordable Care Act, Sen. Bernie Sanders said on Saturday during a 90-minute presentation at The New Yorker Festival. Then on Sunday The New York Times published a report detailing how the Kochs and others bankrolled a coalition of conservative activists pushing to repeal the health care law and threatening Republicans who won’t go along with closing the government to try to get their way.

Their agenda is to end Social Security and Medicare, abolish the minimum wage, destroy the EPA and undo every other program enacted in the past half century to protect working families in America, Sanders added.

I agree with David that citing an historical similarity with current manipulative techniques may be relevant, and informative, and need not characterize a remark or its author or its speaker as hyperbolic.

But, when John Burton incautiously and trenchantly compared Paul Ryan's tactical propaganda with Joseph Goebbles and Adolf Hitler's "Big Lie" the reactionary right took advantage of this incident as legitimization of hyperbole.

And now, as Karen observed, we are engulfed by this dreck; and the effect is numbing.

The caution Mr. Bruni advocates is well advised; we will be better off without invidious headlines and gratuitous references to historical catastrophe; "we should watch our words" and, as well, those of others.

Yet, practitioners of political chicanery advance their agenda through hyperbolic speech, to arouse those who are, through historical and geographical accident, uninformed, misinformed, indoctrinated, bewildered, anxious, and frightened.

We should be alert to such behavior; and, we should call out those who practice an artistry described succinctly by Professor Harry G. Frankfurt of Princeton.

I am disturbed by the implication that we should not use the Nazi analogy. The Nazi's were a fringe group who came to power through a well organized propaganda campaign that misled and frightened a segment of the German population. They were never a majority party but were able to gain power through lies, manipulation and intimidation and the aid of wealthy business people and journalists. Many people both in Germany shrugged off the craziness as temporary or even praised them as good for Germany. Many of these cognoscenti derided those who warned about what was happening as overreacting hand wringers. By the time they gained control of the government it was too late to stop them. Even then prominent people such as Charles Lindbergh, Joseph Kennedy, and King Edward VIII shrugged of the danger in favor of appeasement.

We should have learned from this experience that the way to prevent radical movements from taking over is to nip them in the bud whenever we see tactics such as intimidation, fear-mongering and extensive, dishonest propaganda to promote radical ideas being used instead of turning a blind eye until the destructuve people who are willing to use such anti-democtratic tactics gain enough power to affect our entire country. Sadly what too many seem to believe is that the Nazis were an isolated case that can't happen here which only increases the likelihood that radicals will succeed in dismantling our democracy. It has already begun.

I agree that we should be quite aware of the similarities and the dangers. it is what I was thinking about when the Patriot Act was first passed (that and the fact that the old Soviets were probably laughing in their graves at the "winner" of the Cold War). At what point will we consider DC to be so dysfunctional that we would welcome a dictator (anyone who will take charge and take action!) with open arms...? I hope never, but I can't be sure.

Haven't you heard? The US is running a deficit over $50 billion each month. (It was much higher a few years ago.) That means we have to borrow that much to pay the bills. The debt CEILING limits how much can be borrowed, and therefore how much can be spent.

Umm... no. It's *all* debt, whether interest payments on bonds or payments to military contractors or salaries to federal employees. One type of payment does not use a different type of money from another. While China may be thrilled that you value bond interest above all else, if the U.S. Treasury does not have the cash to make any of these other types of payments the U.S. has still defaulted.

Let's say you're in personal financial trouble, but manage to cover the interest on your mounting credit-card bills for one more month. Your local grocer still expects you to pay when you leave the store with food.

Your statement "In 2011 the Republican House endeavored to prevent this political maneuvering..." is jaw-droppingly fact-averse. The Republican House was (and is) the entity performing the political maneuvering by issuing extra-constitutional ransom demands and attempting to nullify duly enacted laws.

Finally, there is no constitutional requirement for a "debt ceiling" law to begin with. The debt ceiling could straightforwardly be raised to infinity or abolished altogether, but modern House Republicans would never agree to having their ransom vehicle taken away.

My hope is that the Dems stand strong and force the GOP to cave so this can never be used as an absurd weapon again.

This article perpetuates more nonsense.  The US Government takes in more than enough money in tax receipts to easily pay off its bond and debt holders with ease.  Debt payments, which is what is referred to when one worries about "defaulting on the debt", constitute only about 6% of the Federal budget.  The only reason debt wouldn't be paid is that a politically motivated treasury, following the directives of Obama, would decide that more political gain could be obtained by not paying the debt and blaming the economic catastrophe on the Republicans.  In 2011 the Republican House endeavored to prevent this political maneuvering with the full faith and credit act which passed the House but failed on a partisan vote in the Senate.  That act would've mandated that the Treasury pay off debt first so that a default would be impossible, notwithstanding the political desires of this or any future president.  Congress should immediately pass this sensible bill and put to immediate rest any talk, idle or not, of a debt default.
